headline: Heard on the Street Recap: The Fed’s in a Tight Spot
summary: Suspense is building in the market ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest-rate announcement coming Wednesday afternoon.  Retail sales rose 0.6% in August, which was higher than the 0.3% rise economists had predicted.  Stronger retail sales may complicate the case for numerous interest rate cuts if central bankers believe inflation is still a risk.

headline: US senators demand Meta's internal data on kids' safety
summary: (Reuters) -A bipartisan group of U.S. senators demanded Meta Platforms hand over internal assessments of how its products affect children and the effectiveness of its parental controls, according to a letter seen by Reuters.  The 10 senators led by Marsha Blackburn, a Republican from Tennessee, made the demand a week after a Senate hearing where former Meta safety researchers said the company shut down internal research showing Meta knew children were using its VR products and being exposed to sexually explicit material.

headline: Bessent says framework deal for TikTok has been reached, Reuters reports
summary: A framework for a deal on TikTok had been reached in trade talks with China in Madrid, in a move that would pave the way for a switch to U.S. ownership, U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said on Monday, Reuters’ David Lawder and Pietro Lombardi report. Further details will be determined in a meeting between U.S. President Donald Trump and Chinese Premier Xi Jinping when they speak on Friday, Bessent said. Publicly traded companies in the social media space include Meta Platforms (META), Pint

headline: MetaRouter and Vantage Partner to Unlock the Full Value of First-Party Data for Retail Media
summary: DENVER, September 16, 2025--MetaRouter, the leading customer data infrastructure platform, today announced a strategic partnership with Vantage, the only end-to-end retail media orchestration platform, to help retailers unlock and scale the value of their first-party data while giving advertisers faster, more effective campaign activation.

headline: Tech Weekly: slim phones and smart glasses
summary: STORY: From how the iPhone slimmed down, to who’s donning smart glasses, this is Tech Weekly.:: Tech Weekly:: AppleApple launched its latest gadgets.Company boss Tim Cook had big claims for the new iPhone Air:“We're taking the biggest leap ever for iPhone.”The tech giant says this is its slimmest smartphone yet.But critics noted a lack of big updates on AI, where Apple is widely seen to be lagging rivals.Oracle was once seen as an AI laggard too, but that’s all changed.Its shares climbed over 35% in one day after a blockbuster forecast for sales related to the new tech.The Wall Street Journal says it has a cloud computing deal with OpenAI worth $300 billion - among the biggest in history.Meta could soon have a new rival for its augmented reality glasses.:: MetaTech publication The Information says Amazon is developing a competing product.Its rival to the Meta spectacles will reportedly feature microphones, speakers, a camera and a full-color display in one eye.:: MetaThe report says a launch could come late next year, or early 2027.Australia has told social media platforms to use minimally invasive methods to check the ages of users covered by its world-first teen social media ban.The country’s eSafety Commissioner said firms could use existing data to reliably infer users’ ages.Governments and companies are closely watching the effort to block social media use by under 16s, which kicks in from December.And Alphabet has joined the three trillion dollars club.Its valuation has now gone above that level, giving it membership of a select group including Apple, Microsoft and Nvidia.Shares in the Google parent are up around a third this year amid AI enthusiasm.A recent court ruling that it doesn’t have to sell off its Chrome browser or Android phone operating system has also helped.

raw.headline: Tech Weekly: slim phones and smart glasses
raw.summary: STORY: From how the iPhone slimmed down, to who’s donning smart glasses, this is Tech Weekly.:: Tech Weekly:: AppleApple launched its latest gadgets.Company boss Tim Cook had big claims for the new iPhone Air:“We're taking the biggest leap ever for iPhone.”The tech giant says this is its slimmest smartphone yet.But critics noted a lack of big updates on AI, where Apple is widely seen to be lagging rivals.Oracle was once seen as an AI laggard too, but that’s all changed.Its shares climbed over 35% in one day after a blockbuster forecast for sales related to the new tech.The Wall Street Journal says it has a cloud computing deal with OpenAI worth $300 billion - among the biggest in history.Meta could soon have a new rival for its augmented reality glasses.:: MetaTech publication The Information says Amazon is developing a competing product.Its rival to the Meta spectacles will reportedly feature microphones, speakers, a camera and a full-color display in one eye.:: MetaThe report says a launch could come late next year, or early 2027.Australia has told social media platforms to use minimally invasive methods to check the ages of users covered by its world-first teen social media ban.The country’s eSafety Commissioner said firms could use existing data to reliably infer users’ ages.Governments and companies are closely watching the effort to block social media use by under 16s, which kicks in from December.And Alphabet has joined the three trillion dollars club.Its valuation has now gone above that level, giving it membership of a select group including Apple, Microsoft and Nvidia.Shares in the Google parent are up around a third this year amid AI enthusiasm.A recent court ruling that it doesn’t have to sell off its Chrome browser or Android phone operating system has also helped.

headline: Meta to debut costlier smart glasses with display at annual Connect event
summary: (Reuters) -Meta is expected to double down on AI-powered augmented reality products with new smart glasses at its annual Connect event on Wednesday, even as the company faces scrutiny over its handling of child safety on its social media platforms.  At its Menlo Park, California-based headquarters, CEO Mark Zuckerberg is expected to unveil Meta's first consumer-ready smart glasses with a built-in display, a device that analysts predicted will retail for about $800.  Internally codenamed "Hypernova,” the glasses are expected to be launched as "Celeste," analysts said, and will feature a small digital display in the right lens for basic functions such as notifications.

raw.headline: Meta to debut costlier smart glasses with display at annual Connect event
raw.summary: (Reuters) -Meta is expected to double down on AI-powered augmented reality products with new smart glasses at its annual Connect event on Wednesday, even as the company faces scrutiny over its handling of child safety on its social media platforms.  At its Menlo Park, California-based headquarters, CEO Mark Zuckerberg is expected to unveil Meta's first consumer-ready smart glasses with a built-in display, a device that analysts predicted will retail for about $800.  Internally codenamed "Hypernova,” the glasses are expected to be launched as "Celeste," analysts said, and will feature a small digital display in the right lens for basic functions such as notifications.

headline: Valuation Angst Shifts From Big Tech to Rest of S&P 500
summary: It’s the rest of the market that is starting to look a bit overpriced, according to Seaport Research Partners.  An index of S&P 500 companies that excludes the technology sector has risen a solid 13% over the last year, but has seen profits grow by just 6.4%, according to data compiled by Bloomberg Intelligence.
